content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

My first impression of this thumbnail is a sample of adipose tissue containing several lymph nodes, which is typical for a colorectal cancer resection specimen. I can identify at least three distinct nodular structures. The one on the far right is large and densely basophilic (dark purple), strongly suggesting it is a lymph node completely replaced by metastatic tumor. The other, smaller structures to its left also appear to be lymph nodes that require closer examination.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my task is to identify all positive lymph nodes to accurately stage the cancer. After noting the obviously positive node on the right, I would systematically examine every other potential lymph node. The area in the green box contains another discrete, basophilic, nodular structure, which is the second lymph node from the right. I am zooming in to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification to determine if it also contains metastatic tumor cells, which might be a small focus (micrometastasis) and not visible at this low power. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is located at the periphery of the largest and most suspicious-looking lymph node on the slide. Specifically, the zoom target is on the capsule and the subcapsular sinus. This is a critical area to examine because metastatic cells that travel through the lymphatic system often first lodge and grow in the subcapsular sinus. By examining this interface, I am looking for evidence of tumor cells breaching the capsule (extranodal extension) or filling the subcapsular sinus, which are key features in determining if a lymph node is positive for metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is located at the edge of the most suspicious-looking lymph node (the large one on the right). Pathologists systematically examine lymph nodes for metastasis, paying close attention to the subcapsular sinus (just under the capsule) and the hilum, as these are common initial sites for tumor cell deposition. This specific location at the periphery of the lymphoid aggregate allows for assessment of potential invasion from surrounding tissue or deposition in the sinus. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the largest and most suspicious lymph node (the second distinct node from the top, located on the right). My reason for zooming into this specific area, at the periphery of the node, is twofold. First, to confirm that the dense basophilic cells are indeed metastatic carcinoma by examining their cytological features (e.g., large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, glandular formation). Second, and more importantly, this interface between the node and the surrounding fat is the critical location to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor beyond the lymph node capsule. ENE is a key prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is part of the largest and most abnormal-looking lymph node on the slide. On low power, this node is almost entirely replaced by a basophilic cell population, which is highly suspicious for a massive tumor deposit. My goal is to examine the cellular morphology at high magnification to confirm if these are malignant cells (i.e., adenocarcinoma) and to assess the extent of nodal involvement. This node is the most likely to be positive, so it's the first one I would examine closely. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the largest lymph node on the right. The specific area of interest is the periphery of the node, which includes the capsule and the subcapsular sinus. This is a standard and critical part of lymph node examination because metastatic cancer cells, traveling through lymphatic vessels, typically first implant and grow in the subcapsular sinus. I am looking for clusters of atypical cells in this region. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining the lymph nodes to assess for metastatic disease, which is crucial for staging colorectal cancer. I have selected this specific lymph node on the right for closer inspection because its large size and solid, intensely basophilic appearance on low power are strong indicators of tumor involvement. A reactive lymph node would typically show more defined follicular structures. The goal is to magnify the area to confirm if the cellular infiltrate consists of malignant epithelial cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a section of a lymph node. The node is heavily infiltrated by a dense population of cells. While many are small, dark lymphocytes, there are distinct clusters and sheets of larger, atypical cells with more abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and irregular nuclei. These clusters are particularly evident in the upper left portion. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is another positive lymph node, confirming the presence of metastatic disease.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the edge of the lymph node. At the top, there is per-nodal fibroconnective tissue. Below this is the pink, fibrous capsule of the lymph node. Directly beneath the capsule is the subcapsular sinus. The bulk of the image at the bottom is composed of densely packed, small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes, forming the cortex of the lymph node. In this specific field, the subcapsular sinus appears open and contains a few scattered histiocytes but no definite clusters of malignant cells. The capsule itself does not appear to be infiltrated. My impression for this specific field is that it is negative for metastasis. However, a complete evaluation requires examining the entire circumference of the node and its interior.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense population of lymphoid cells. There are sheets of small, dark lymphocytes and a somewhat organized structure that resembles a lymphoid follicle. A large, congested blood vessel filled with red blood cells is prominent in the lower part of the image, situated in the surrounding connective tissue. Crucially, in this specific field of view, there are no definite malignant epithelial cells, such as atypical glands or nests of adenocarcinoma. The appearance is that of a reactive lymph node with prominent lymphoid follicles and vascular congestion. To make a final diagnosis, I would need to continue scanning the entire lymph node, as metastasis could be present in other areas.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, there is a clear demarcation between two cell populations. On the upper left, there is a dense sheet of residual small, dark lymphocytes. In contrast, infiltrating the stroma and adipose tissue in the center and bottom of the image are nests and single cells of a malignant tumor. These tumor cells are much larger, with abundant pink (eosinophilic) cytoplasm and large, irregular (pleomorphic) nuclei. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells are clearly seen invading into the fibro-adipose tissue surrounding the lymph node. My impression is a positive lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma and definite extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense, solid sheet of malignant cells that has replaced the normal lymphoid tissue. The cells are poorly differentiated, with large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei, irregular nuclear contours, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. There is little to no gland formation visible in this particular field. My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming this is a positive lymph node. The tumor appears to be infiltrating in a solid pattern.
This is ROI 6. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I can see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node and the underlying lymphoid tissue. Within the subcapsular sinus, there are distinct clusters of large, atypical cells with abundant pink (eosinophilic) cytoplasm and enlarged, irregular nuclei. These cells are clearly different from the surrounding small, dark lymphocytes and are forming small, poorly-defined glandular structures. My impression is that this represents metastatic adenocarcinoma in the subcapsular sinus, making this a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the normal lymph node architecture is completely replaced by sheets and nests of malignant cells. The cells exhibit significant nuclear atypia, including hyperchromasia (darkly stained nuclei), irregular nuclear contours, and pleomorphism (variation in size and shape). They are arranged in poorly formed, crowded glandular structures. The overall features are unequivocally those of metastatic adenocarcinoma. This confirms that the lymph node is positive for metastasis.
